author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: The Old Man?
description: Sam Ezersky’s themeless Saturday grid will get you going.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Except for its difficulty level, this themeless construction by Sam Ezersky reads like a scroll on your social media feed of choice: haute and bas cuisine, fashion, gadgets and brands galore, with an occasional nostalgic reference to a thing that existed before we all essentially attained oneness with our smartphones. I imagine that solvers who have somehow inoculated themselves against the seemingly infinite content at our disposal found a high degree of novelty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Has the Spread of Tipping Reached Its Limit? Don’t Count on It.
description: Both major presidential candidates propose exempting tips from taxes. That could encourage more reliance on tipping, and leave workers vulnerable.
content: Americans are being asked to tip more often and in more places than ever before: at fast food counters and corner stores, at auto garages and carwashes, even at self-checkout kiosks. That has rankled many customers and divided both employers and tipped workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Product Integration
description: September, already? Chandi Deitmer and Matthew Stock’s puzzle tosses some math into the mix.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Trump Says He’ll Vote Against Florida’s Abortion Rights Measure After Conservative Backlash
description: A day earlier, the former president had suggested he might support the measure, which would expand abortion access in the state.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Friday that he would vote against a ballot measure in Florida that would expand abortion access in the state, clarifying his stance after having suggested a day earlier that he might support the measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: A New Statue of a British Colonialist Exposes a Divide in Singapore
description: The tribute to Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles, who is considered the founder of Singapore, has raised questions about how the wealthy city-state perceives its history.
content: Singapore’s prosperity has long set it apart from many other former British colonies. There is another difference, too: Singapore has clung to honoring its former colonial ruler — and it wants to keep doing so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Wendy Dorr, Paula Szuchman, Rowan Niemisto, Melissa Kirsch and Lisa Miller
title: We Can’t All Be BFFs. Enter the ‘Medium Friend.’
description: The less intense bonds you didn’t know you needed.
content: Lisa Miller, a Times reporter, recently wrote about the concept of the “medium friend,” a person with whom you’re not intimate enough to be considered a best friend, but not distant enough to be considered an acquaintance. Miller argued that medium friends can bring joy to a person’s life, but that friendships that defy easy categorization can create painful misunderstandings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: After Beating Alcaraz, a Dutch Player Keeps His ‘Lucky Charms’ Close
description: Botic van de Zandschulp’s career has had its ups and downs. But a pair of Manhattan financiers he knew as a boy in the Netherlands have become part of his “team.”
content: Botic van de Zandschulp, a Dutch tennis player, scored one of the biggest upsets of the United States Open when he stunned the four-time grand slam champion Carlos Alcaraz in the second round on Thursday. Coming from a player ranked No. 74 in the world, it may have seemed shocking, but Mr. van de Zandschulp has enjoyed the greatest successes of his career at the Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Contorts Himself on Abortion in Search of Political Gain
description: The former president is willing to make as many rhetorical and policy shifts as he deems necessary to win in November, vexing some social conservatives.
content: At the age of 53, in a 1999 interview on NBC’s “Meet the Press,” Donald J. Trump described himself as “very pro-choice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Maybe We Are Asking Presidential Candidates the Wrong Questions
description: Harris needs to talk about her theory of the presidency, not relitigate her campaign controversies.
content: If the goal of the CNN interview with Vice President Kamala Harris and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota was to relitigate the campaign controversies of the last month — to get the candidates to talk about the major narratives of the election so far — then it was a rousing success. Harris easily dispatched questions about her identity and gave a strong defense of President Biden’s record. Walz, likewise, made short work of the charge that he had misled the public when he spoke about using one fertility treatment when it was actually another, similar treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Arthur J. Gregg, His Name Replacing Lee’s on a Virginia Fort, Dies at 96
description: The first Black Army officer elevated to lieutenant general, he lived to see a military post named for a slaveholding Confederate general rechristened in his honor.
content: Arthur J. Gregg, the first African American Army officer to reach the rank of lieutenant general and the only person in modern history to have a military base named for him in his lifetime — in his case a rechristening of a fort that had honored the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee — died on Aug. 22. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik
title: More Voters, Especially Women, Now Say Abortion Is Their Top Issue
description: Donald J. Trump is shifting his stance on reproductive rights, but voters, by a wide margin, say that they trust Kamala Harris on the issue.
content: Attitudes on abortion are deeply entrenched and have motivated voters across the American political landscape for decades. But in a post-Roe world, with abortion access sharply limited or at stake in several states, voters who want to protect abortion rights are increasingly energized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner and Kimberly Cortez
title: 3 Dead After Small Plane Crashes Into Oregon Townhouses
description: A Cessna crashed into a row of townhouses in Fairview, Ore., on Saturday, sparking a large fire, officials said.
content: Three people were killed after a small plane crashed on Saturday morning in a residential neighborhood in Fairview, Ore., according to the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MJ Franklin
title: A Veteran Falls in Love With a Beautiful Woman, Including Her Spiraled Horn
description: The itinerant man in Gayl Jones’s “The Unicorn Woman” discovers his beloved as a sideshow carnival attraction.
content: Early on in Gayl Jones’s new novel, “The Unicorn Woman,” a tractor repairman issues a warning: “Women that make you a dreamer are never what you expect,” he says. “They’re all illusion and confusion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Ormont Blumberg
title: Can You Have a Stylish Wedding for Under $5,000? These Couples Did.
description: The national average wedding expense rose to more than $30,000 in 2024. Here’s how to plan a lovely wedding without breaking the bank.
content: For Jessica Bishop, who formerly worked in marketing, starting BudgetSavvyBride.com in 2008 was personal. Newly engaged during the Great Recession, she had wondered, “How do I have this dream wedding on the budget that I can actually afford?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Michael Gold
title: Trump Signals Support for Marijuana Legalization in Florida
description: “Whether people like it or not, this will happen,” former President Donald J. Trump said on Saturday. Gov. Ron DeSantis opposes the measure.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday signaled his support for a ballot measure that would legalize recreational marijuana in Florida, stopping short of a full endorsement but saying that he did not believe marijuana should be criminalized in his adopted home state when it is legal in others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: America Does Not Need the Death Penalty
description: President Biden should fulfill his promise to work to pass legislation to end the use of capital punishment for federal crimes.
content: Capital punishment is not a front-burner political issue this year. In fact, the Democratic Party dropped the subject from its 2024 platform, eight years after becoming the first major party to formally call for abolishing the death penalty. But in 2020, President Biden’s campaign platform included a pledge to “work to pass legislation to eliminate the death penalty at the federal level, and incentivize states to follow the federal government’s example.” Once elected, he became the country’s first sitting president openly opposed to capital punishment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Deepfake Musk’ Stars in Scams Across the Internet
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 31, 2024.
content: “But as far as the picture, if somebody had said, ‘Pick him out of a lineup,’ that’s him.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Gaza, Lebanon, West Bank: Why Is Israel Fighting So Many Wars?
description: As well as its conflict with Hamas, Israel is battling along its border with Lebanon, waging a counterinsurgency in the occupied West Bank and exchanging sporadic fire with Iran and its regional proxies.
content: While Israel’s devastating war with Hamas in Gaza attracts the most attention, its military has also been fighting for months on several other fronts, making this one of the most complex periods of conflict in the country’s 76-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Rosenbluth
title: What’s in Your Fridge? Here Are Details About the Deli Meat Listeria Recall
description: Seven million pounds of Boar’s Head meats have been recalled since late July, when reports of serious illnesses and deaths began to occur.
content: In the last month, nine people have died and dozens have been hospitalized in a listeria outbreak linked to Boar’s Head deli meats that has led to a recall of seven million pounds of its products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Whistle-Blower Groups Push to End Secret Seizure of Congressional Communications
description: During the Trump administration, the Justice Department subpoenaed congressional aides’ communications without their knowledge while hunting for leakers. Advocates say the practice must stop.
content: As President Donald J. Trump hunted for people inside the government who were divulging details of an investigation into whether his 2016 election campaign colluded with Russia, the Justice Department turned to a covert tactic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: As Ukraine Mourns a Pilot’s Death, Jet’s Crash Is Still a Mystery
description: In a reversal, two senior U.S. military officials say the cause of the F-16’s crash was probably not friendly fire.
content: As hundreds of Russian missiles and drones streaked across Ukraine on Monday, the Ukrainian fighter pilot known as Moonfish was exactly where he had said he always wanted to be: in the cockpit of an F-16 giving chase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: A Roller Derby Team Becomes a Bastion of Resistance to a Transgender Ban
description: In New York’s Nassau County, the Roller Rebels have joined with civil rights lawyers to face down the Republican county executive, Bruce Blakeman.
content: At 6 feet 4 inches before even lacing up her skates, Jack Sawula towered over most of her teammates at a recent practice of the Long Island Roller Rebels, a women’s roller derby team in suburban Nassau County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Here’s Why We Shouldn’t Demean Trump Voters
description: Educated liberals often view the conservative working class with a whiff of condescension that is both unfair and counterproductive.
content: Some of the best advice Democrats have received recently came from Bill Clinton in his speech at the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Criticizing Trump, Harris Says Arlington Is ‘Not a Place for Politics’
description: Donald J. Trump’s campaign filmed him at Arlington National Cemetery on Monday, which led to a confrontation between one of his political aides and a cemetery official.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris excoriated former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday for his visit on Monday to Arlington National Cemetery, where his campaign’s filming of him in a heavily restricted area caused a confrontation between one of his political aides and a cemetery official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Hurling in Ireland: Is the ‘Clash of the Ash’ Becoming a ‘Battle of Bamboo’?
description: For centuries, the sport’s wooden sticks have been made from Ireland’s ash trees. But with a disease destroying forests, the ancient game is turning to different materials.
content: The horde of helmeted players raced up the field like warriors headed into battle, with the slap of a ball against the wooden sticks they wielded, known as hurleys, ringing out as they sped toward the goal posts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Says It Has Recovered More Bodies in Gaza
description: The Israeli military asked the public not to speculate, but many Israelis assumed the announcement referred to dead hostages. The news amplified calls for a cease-fire and hostage-release deal.
content: The Israeli military said on Saturday that it had found a number of dead bodies during an operation in the Gaza Strip, asking the Israeli public to refrain from speculation about their identities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Eiffel Tower Will Keep Olympic Rings Permanently, Mayor Says
description: “I want the two to remain married,” Mayor Anne Hidalgo of Paris said in a newspaper interview.
content: The giant Olympic rings that were installed on the Eiffel Tower for the 2024 summer Games will become a permanent fixture on the monument, the mayor of Paris revealed on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Former Miss Teen USA Contestant Rebukes Vance for Using Her Flub to Attack Harris
description: Caite Upton wrote on social media that “online bullying needs to stop,” after JD Vance posted a clip of her mangled answer from the 2007 Miss Teen USA pageant to mock Kamala Harris.
content: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, who since becoming former President Donald J. Trump’s running mate in July has been criticized on several occasions for comments demeaning women, found himself again embroiled in controversy this week when he used a viral clip of a beauty pageant contestant’s meltdown to attack Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Fatman Scoop, a D.J. and Rapper, Dies at 56
description: Questlove called him “an embodiment of what hip-hop was truly about.” He collapsed onstage while performing in Hamden, Conn.
content: The rapper Fatman Scoop, whose hoarse and booming voice brought an electric energy to songs by Missy Elliott and Mariah Carey, and whose “Be Faithful” was an underground club favorite, died after collapsing onstage during a performance on Friday. He was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 31, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 31, 2024.
content: An article on Friday about a court ruling in South Korea that ordered the government to take stronger action on Climate Change misstated an aspect of the court’s ruling. It gave the National Assembly until the end of February 2026, not February 2025, to revise the Carbon Neutral Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seph Rodney
title: ‘Ice Cold’: From Biggie to Lil Yachty, Getting Your Shine On
description: Hip-hop jewelry does a lot of heavy lifting in a new exhibition in Manhattan. It signifies elite membership, romantic courtship and ambition for greatness.
content: Of the New York museums that would create an exhibition on jewelry associated with hip-hop culture, I would not have imagined the American Museum of Natural History to be one. Yet, “Ice Cold: An Exhibition of Hip-Hop Jewelry” did open this May in a tiny gallery of their Mignone Halls of Gems and Minerals. With 66 objects, it has an astute premise — that precious stones might attract more attention if regarded through the lens of hip-hop, likely the most widely proliferating music movement that the United States has ever produced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: The Constitution Is Sacred. Is It Also Dangerous?
description: One of the biggest threats to America’s politics might be the country’s founding document.
content: The United States Constitution is in trouble. After Donald Trump lost the 2020 election, he called for the “termination of all rules, regulations and articles, even those found in the Constitution.” Outraged critics denounced him for threatening a document that is supposed to be “sacrosanct.” By announcing his desire to throw off constitutional constraints in order to satisfy his personal ambitions, Trump was making his authoritarian inclinations abundantly clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Island Vibes Zucchini Bread
description: It’s not a regular zucchini bread. It’s a cool zucchini bread (with fresh pineapple and flaked coconut).
content: Island vibes zucchini bread! Have you ever heard of a more fun zucchini bread? At its most basic, zucchini bread is friendly and helpful, there for you and your glut of summer squash. This island vibes zucchini bread from Jocelyn Delk Adams is also those things, but it’s wearing shades and slides and teaches bodysurfing on the weekends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Honor Cargill-Martin
title: The Ancient Roots of Trump’s Attacks on Harris
description: The Trump campaign’s attacks on Kamala Harris echo misogynistic attacks on ancient Roman empresses and medieval queens.
content: The meddler, the schemer, the veiled power behind the throne, the poisoner, the witch. The image of sinister female power hiding in the dark permeates our cultural consciousness. It is a trope that stretches back to the ancient world, when women were excluded from politics and men sought ways to prove that their participation would be unnatural and dangerous. As ancient texts became part of the Western canon, such suspicion became ingrained into our patterns of thought, surviving long after the conditions that created them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: Is a Writer a Kind of Spy?
description: In her new novel, Rachel Kushner invents a secret agent who’s not really all that different from a novelist.
content: Rachel Kushner had warned me that there might be snakes and one very mean turkey on the farm. There would also be mud; she recommended rubber boots. And, as far as she remembered, there was no cell service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Sagar Radia Balances His Alpha-Male Energy on ‘Industry’ With Some Alone Time
description: “I think there’s this common misconception that actors are these big extroverts, and I couldn’t disagree more. Most actors I know don’t need to be the center of attention.”
content: Sagar Radia calls Rishi Ramdani, the take-no-prisoners market maker he plays on the HBO finance drama “Industry,” a walking red flag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: A Playlist to Remember
description: Songs can help demarcate this chapter of your life: It’s a way to mark time, to keep one period of time from bleeding indistinctly into the next.
content: I am putting the finishing touches on my Summer 2024 playlist. This isn’t a collection of the summer’s hottest hits, although Chappell Roan and Charli XCX did make it on there. It’s a mix of the songs that I’ve been listening to this summer, regardless of when they came out — more Barack Obama than Billboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Kate Conger
title: How Brazil’s Experiment Fighting Fake News Led to a Ban on X
description: To combat disinformation, Brazil gave one judge broad power to police the internet. Now, after he blocked X, some are wondering whether that was a good idea.
content: As Brazil grappled with a flood of online disinformation around its 2022 presidential election, the nation’s Supreme Court made an unusual and fateful decision: It gave one justice sweeping powers to order social networks to take down content he believed threatened democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis and Ash Adams
title: For Generations of Alaskans, a Livelihood Is Under Threat
description: Something is broken in the economics of the state’s fishing industry and the communities that have long depended upon it. Can Washington come to the rescue?
content: Petersburg, Alaska, is as pretty a seaside town as any you’ll find across the filigree of fjords and foggy islands that make up the state’s maritime coast. Statuary and floral designs evidence its proud Scandinavian heritage, and bald eagles soar across the narrow strait that separates it from a national forest. It doesn’t have room for the giant cruise ships that disgorge thousands of passengers into Ketchikan and Juneau, but it is perfectly situated for its sustaining industry: fishing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ingmar Nolting and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: The Angry East
description: As east Germans vote, a region in decline is searching for answers on the political extremes.
content: Whatever the outcome of the elections on Sunday in the eastern states of Saxony and Thuringia, the far-right Alternative for Germany party long ago stepped from the political fringe and into the mainstream in Görlitz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: The Construction Site Outside My Building Is Filthy. What Can I Do?
description: City codes govern the removal of construction debris, including keeping waste contained.
content: Q: My Queens co-op has been storing construction garbage in the area between our property and the neighboring property for almost two months now. My apartment looks directly onto the garbage, which has attracted rats. The co-op is asking me to be “patient” while it finishes the work and removes trash at the end of the project, but no workers have been on site in weeks, so I think they should immediately remove this trash, which would certainly fill a dumpster. What rights do I have as a shareholder? Is it legal for them to store garbage in our yard?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: 5 Takeaways From Our Reporting on Toxic Sludge Fertilizer
description: The Times dug into the widespread use of sewage sludge as fertilizer, which is sometimes heavily contaminated by “forever chemicals.”
content: For decades, the government has encouraged farmers across the United States to spread sewage sludge on their cropland and pastures. But now there’s a growing awareness that sludge fertilizer can contain heavy concentrations of “forever chemicals” linked to cancer, birth defects and other health risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Kamala Harris Is Breaking Barriers. She Just Isn’t Talking About It.
description: Can she finally move us past identity politics?
content: When Kamala Harris took the stage in Chicago last week, she spoke of her “trailblazer” mother and her encouraging father — “Don’t let anything stop you.” She told of how the sexual abuse of her best friend led her to become a prosecutor. She encouraged people to imagine abortion rights being restored in a Harris presidency. What she did not do, as she described her “unlikely journey,” was state the obvious — and that silence spoke volumes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Nerf Blasters and Lego Rockets: Another Mall Evolution
description: Landlords are turning to companies like Hasbro and Mattel for some fun and games in “retailtainment.”
content: Medical clinics, schools and apartments: For a decade, shopping mall owners have been desperately seeking new options for space vacated by shuttered department stores and bankrupt retailers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Something’s Poisoning America’s Land. Farmers Fear ‘Forever’ Chemicals.
description: Fertilizer made from city sewage has been spread on millions of acres of farmland for decades. Scientists say it can contain high levels of the toxic substance.
content: For decades, farmers across America have been encouraged by the federal government to spread municipal sewage on millions of acres of farmland as fertilizer. It was rich in nutrients, and it helped keep the sludge out of landfills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Conservative Moms, Charmed by Trump, Would Rather Avoid His Misogyny
description: Former President Donald J. Trump spoke at a convention of the Moms for Liberty in Washington.
content: It didn’t look like a typical Trump rally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan and Hurubie Meko
title: Judge Dismisses Suit Seeking to Ban Smoking in Atlantic City Casinos
description: The judge said a loophole exempting casinos from a statewide ban on indoor smoking did not keep workers from pursuing employment in smoke-free environments.
content: A judge dismissed a lawsuit on Friday that sought to ban smoking in Atlantic City, N.J., casinos, a blow to workers who argued that a loophole exempting the establishments from a statewide ban on indoor smoking forced them to work in a “poisonous” environment. The exemption, the judge said, did not keep workers from pursuing employment in smoke-free environments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva
title: Russia’s Youngest Conscripts Unexpectedly See Combat Against Ukraine’s Invasion
description: The long-sacrosanct practice of keeping young Russian army conscripts off the front lines is eroding as the lack of troops in Russia’s Kursk region indicates a manpower shortage.
content: For more than two decades it has been standard practice in Russia: New conscripts doing mandatory military service have not been deployed on the front lines. It is codified in law and embraced by all parents hoping to keep their sons from the carnage of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Sohn
title: The Household Chores You’re Avoiding Are Key to a Deeper Life
description: I used to consider the work I needed to do around the house expendable. I now see it as integral to my and my family’s happiness.
content: In the early days of motherhood, I found myself taking an interest in the steady stream of ads and apps that promised to help my husband and me stay on top of our piling-up chores. Seemingly every household task could be subcontracted for a fee — offers to pick up, clean and fold our laundry; handymen to put together new furniture; sleep experts to sleep-train our toddler; a bevy of meal-kit purveyors, each vying for my attention with promotional postcards and sign-up bonuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Picard
title: How a Sober-ish Writer Spends Her Sundays
description: Hilary Sheinbaum, who wrote “The Dry Challenge,” spends her Sundays running, gossiping over tennis and not (really) drinking alcohol.
content: When Hilary Sheinbaum first heard about Dry January, the concept of giving up alcohol for a month did not compute. A friend mentioned it to her over dinner several years ago, but she wasn’t interested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: New York City’s Piers, Once Abandoned, Are Now Full of Life
description: In each of New York City’s boroughs, decrepit piers that once fed city industries have been brought back to life. Out over the water, they offer beauty, fun and respite from the city’s buzz.
content: When the sun comes out, New Yorkers flock to the city’s piers. They bring picnic blankets and coolers, sunscreen and speakers, to places where decades ago longshoremen unloaded goods from cargo ships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stan Cox
title: I Swore Off Air-Conditioning, and You Can, Too
description: The more time we can spend outside or inside without the air-conditioner blasting, the better prepared we’ll be — both to slow climate change and to adapt to it.
content: Whenever people ask me how my wife and I have endured 25 Kansas summers almost entirely without air-conditioning, I like to say we do it because air-conditioning makes it too hot outside. We’re not ascetics, Luddites or misers; we just want to keep living comfortably, indoors and out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Kate Conger
title: With X Blocked, Brazilians Find New Homes for Their Thoughts
description: The platform went dark across Brazil on Saturday, sending online commentators to new digital town squares.
content: As the clock struck midnight in Brazil, the feed stopped refreshing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 448
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Sept. 1, 2024.
content: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level and if you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Hvaldimir, a Celebrated ‘Spy’ Whale, Is Found Dead in Norway
description: The beluga whale, who was first spotted in 2019 wearing what looked like a camera harness, was seen floating in Norwegian waters on Saturday.
content: Hvaldimir, a beluga whale who had captured the public’s imagination since 2019 after he was spotted wearing a harness seemingly designed for a camera, was found dead on Saturday in Norway, according to a nonprofit that worked to protect the whale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Will Alberta Replace the Mounties With Its Own Provincial Police Force?
description: Danielle Smith, the premier, told party supporters that the government would expand the role of its sheriffs.
content: Along with pulling out of the Canada Pension Plan, Danielle Smith, the premier of Alberta, has in the past floated the idea of replacing the Royal Canadian Mounted Police with a provincial police force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: What We Know About the Polio Crisis in Gaza
description: Israel and Hamas have agreed to brief pauses in fighting so that humanitarian workers can begin an inoculation campaign.
content: A mass polio vaccination campaign for young children will begin in the Gaza Strip on Sunday, an especially challenging effort in a war zone where hundreds of thousands of people have been displaced repeatedly, buildings and infrastructure have been destroyed and moving around is often dangerous for aid workers and civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,170
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 1, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: 7 Killed in Mississippi Bus Crash, Including a Pair of Siblings
description: The passenger bus overturned about 40 miles west of Jackson after it experienced “tire failure” early on Saturday, officials said.
content: Seven people were killed after a passenger bus overturned east of Vicksburg, Miss., early on Saturday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terry Tempest Williams and Michael Lundgren
title: When the Flash Flood Comes With Godlike Velocity, Why Do I Stay and Watch?
description: This series of floods didn’t force us to leave. But the next ones might.
content: Something is coming. I smell it before I hear it, and I hear it before I see it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Hiker Is Found Dead in Grand Canyon National Park
description: The 60-year-old from North Carolina was on a multiday backpacking trip. His death was the sixth reported inside the Arizona park this month.
content: The body of a hiker was found on a remote trail in Grand Canyon National Park in Arizona in what was the sixth death reported in the sprawling park this month, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: San Diego School Superintendent Is Fired After Misconduct Investigation
description: Lamont Jackson, who led California’s second-largest school district, engaged in “unwelcome, sex-based behavior” toward two female employees, the investigation found.
content: The superintendent of the San Diego Unified School District was fired on Friday after an investigation had found that he had acted inappropriately toward two female employees, district officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Seek Simpler Path in Federal Election Case, as Trump Seeks Delays
description: In a court filing, prosecutors suggested their revisions would let them steer clear of the Supreme Court ruling on immunity. Donald Trump’s lawyers made clear they would continue broad attacks on the case.
content: Federal prosecutors and lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump filed dueling proposals on Friday night about how to move forward in the case accusing him of plotting to overturn the 2020 election in light of the Supreme Court’s landmark ruling on presidential immunity and other legal issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: As Israel Keeps Fighting in West Bank, Residents in One Battle Zone Reel From the Damage
description: In the Nur Shams area near Tulkarm, Israeli bulldozers have chewed up large chunks of the roads, and many homes have been left without running water and internet. One family mourned the death of a relative they said was killed in the raid.
content: Residents of Tulkarm in the Israeli-occupied West Bank assessed the damage on Saturday from a raid by Israeli forces that has chewed up roads, brought sudden bouts of violence and left many Palestinians reeling. Israel’s military pressed on elsewhere in the territory amid signs that fighting with Palestinian militant groups could spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: LL Cool J Can’t Stop, Won’t Stop. (And Why Would He?)
description: At 56, the hip-hop eminence and TV star can slip into Russian, stun arenas and delight executives. With Q-Tip as a producer, he’s returning to his first love: rap.
content: At a dusty studio space in an industrial corner of Los Angeles, LL Cool J bounced and vibed in black satin and bulging, size 13 Balenciaga boots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: Dallas Police Officer ‘Executed’ in Premeditated Attack, Officials Say
description: Two other officers were also shot, and one of them remains hospitalized. After a pursuit, the suspect was killed by the police, authorities said.
content: A police officer in Dallas was fatally shot on Thursday night in what officials described as a premeditated execution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: In North Carolina, the Math for a Supermajority May Come Down to One
description: It’s one of several states where legislators of one party have overridden vetoes from a governor of the opposing party. Several tossup races will determine if that continues.
content: This fall, as Democrats and Republicans vie for control of state legislatures across the country, much of the attention has focused on states like Michigan, Pennsylvania and Arizona, where one or two seats could tip the balance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: JD Vance’s Combative Style Confounds Democrats but Pleases Trump
description: Over dozens of events and more than 70 interviews, Mr. Vance’s performances as Donald Trump’s attack dog have endeared him to his boss, even if America broadly is less enthusiastic.
content: Donald J. Trump knew that JD Vance could take a punch. But during their first week together on the campaign trail, the former president wondered just how many hits his new running mate could absorb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadie Stein
title: These Two Books Ask, Was the Movie Better?
description: The French novel that was adapted into “Vertigo”; Cameron Crowe’s nonfiction account of a year inside a public high school.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Athlete Accused of Abuse Had Harassed Other Paralympians, Lawsuit Claims
description: A para swimmer who sued the U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee in 2022 now says it knew that the teammate he accused of rape was a threat.
content: At the last Paralympic Games, in Tokyo, Parker Egbert reached the height of his athletic career, competing for the United States in two swimming events. But Mr. Egbert, 21, has since walked away from the sport. He said in a federal lawsuit in 2022 that he was repeatedly physically and sexually abused by his Paralympic teammate, including at the Tokyo Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henrik Pryser Libell and Lynsey Chutel
title: A Fairy Tale for Netflix: A Norwegian Princess Weds an American Shaman
description: The nuptials of Princess Martha Louise and Durek Verrett attracted huge public interest and a streaming deal for a couple trying to reclaim their narrative after years of bad press.
content: There was no castle, nor were there throngs of exuberant crowds to celebrate this royal wedding. Nonetheless, the nuptials on Saturday of a Norwegian princess and an American self-described shaman attracted public fascination at home and a Netflix deal abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape and Allison McCann
title: In College Sports’ Big Money Era, Here’s Where the Dollars Go
description: On average, $1 million for S.E.C. quarterbacks; guards who earn a quarter of that: The New York Times examined the so-called Black Book, a kind of Zillow for college sports, that details athletes’ expected annual pay.
content: On average, $1 million for S.E.C. quarterbacks; guards who earn a quarter of that: The New York Times examined the so-called Black Book, a kind of Zillow for college sports, that details athletes’ expected annual pay.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Plane Crashes Into Townhouses in Oregon
description: A small plane struck a row of townhouses in Fairview, Ore., killing two people on board and one person in a house, according to the authorities.
content: A small plane struck a row of townhouses in Fairview, Ore., killing two people on board and one person in a house, according to the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times
